figures.description: Production‑function diagram for Question 6. Horizontal axis: variable factor input; vertical axis: output. The curve rises from the origin and passes through points I, J, K and L. The slope increases up to J (increasing marginal product) and then decreases from J to K to L (diminishing marginal product). Diminishing returns set in at point J, where marginal product begins to fall though total product is still rising.

Production possibility curve of country X for Question 12. Vertical axis: capital goods; horizontal axis: consumer goods. The frontier is a downward‑sloping concave curve from point W on the vertical axis to point N on the horizontal axis. Points Y and Z lie on the curve, while point X lies strictly inside the curve, indicating under‑utilization of resources.

Demand and supply schedule for Questions 20 and 21. Table columns: Price (N), Quantity Demanded, Quantity Supplied. Rows: (10, 50, 450), (20, 150, 350), (30, 250, 250), (40, 350, 150), (50, 450, 50). Equilibrium occurs at price N30 where quantity demanded equals quantity supplied (250 units).

Total‑revenue schedule for Question 22. Price is fixed at N5. Quantities sold successively: 15, 16, 17, 18 units. Total revenue rises in equal increments of N5, so marginal revenue \(MR = \Delta TR / \Delta Q = 5\) naira.

instructions.text: In each of questions 1 to 50, choose the option that best answers the question or completes the statement.

questions.question: The basic economic problems of the society include

options.text: what to produce, how and for whom
scarcity, when to produce and how
scarcity, for whom to produce and where

questions.explanation: The fundamental economic questions are **what to produce, how to produce and for whom to produce**.

questions.question: Opportunity cost is an economic cost and an economic concept which describes the

options.text: monetary equivalent of the utility of a commodity
amount of time or money invested on a commodity
sacrifice made for the satisfaction of a want
cost of retaining an optimum level of production of commodities

questions.explanation: Opportunity cost is the **value of the best alternative forgone** when a choice is made.

questions.question: If the marginal propensity to consume is 0.80 and the investment expenditure changes from N100 million to N140 million in a given economy, find the change in equilibrium income using the multiplier formula \(K = \dfrac{1}{1 - MPC}\).
questions.explanation: With \(MPC = 0.8\), \(K = 1/(1-0.8) = 5\). The change in investment is \(\Delta I = 40\) million, so \(\Delta Y = K\Delta I = 5 \times 40 = 200\) million.

questions.question: The circular flow of income defines the

options.text: relationship between ends and means in the economic system
allocation of income to various members of the household
flow of goods, services and money among the various macro‑sectors of the economy

questions.explanation: The circular‑flow model shows how **goods, services and money** move between households, firms, government and the rest of the world.

questions.question: The necessity of choice is due to the fact that
questions.explanation: Because wants are unlimited but resources are scarce, individuals and societies **must choose** how to allocate them.

questions.question: The graph in figure Econ1994_ProdFunction_Diminishing represents a production function. At which of the points does diminishing returns set in?
questions.explanation: Diminishing returns begin where **marginal product starts to fall**, i.e. where the total‑product curve becomes less steep; this occurs at point J.

questions.question: In a mixed economy, decisions to produce are taken by

options.text: men and women acting in their own best interest
the government acting in the interest of the country
the market women, the labour unions and the employers’ association
private individuals, organizations and the government

questions.explanation: In a **mixed economy** both the private sector and the government make production decisions.

questions.question: Every economy requires an accurate census because it assists in

options.text: providing a sound framework for policy formulation
stimulating economic activities in the national economy

questions.explanation: Reliable population data provide a **basis for planning and policy formulation**.

questions.question: The population of country X in 1990 was 35 million. The births were 450,000 while it recorded 210,000 deaths. In the same year, its immigrants were 20,000 and 10,000 of its citizens left the country. Calculate the total population of the country at the end of 1990.
If the actual population in a country is less than the optimum population, then

options.text: it is desirable to have a large population
it is necessary to have an improved technology to sustain the population
it is desirable to have a smaller population
the available resources are inadequate to sustain the population

questions.explanation: When population is **below optimum**, additional people raise output per head, so it is desirable for population to grow.

questions.question: Unemployment can be reduced by

options.text: restricting the productive base of the economy
adopting more labour‑intensive techniques of production
adopting a mixture of labour‑ and capital‑intensive techniques of production

questions.explanation: In labour‑surplus developing countries, using **labour‑intensive methods** helps absorb more workers and reduce unemployment.

questions.question: Refer to the production possibility curve of country X in figure Econ1994_PPC_CountryX. If the economy is operating at point X (inside the curve), the implication is that

options.text: the productive capacity is being fully utilized
the productive capacity is not being fully utilized
too little of consumer goods is being produced
there is a disequilibrium between the production of capital and consumer goods

questions.explanation: Point X lies **inside** the PPF, indicating unemployment or under‑utilization of resources.

questions.question: When the Total Product (TP) is at its maximum point, the Marginal Product (MP) and the Average Product (AP) respectively are
questions.explanation: TP is maximized when **MP = 0**; at that point AP has already started to fall.

questions.question: In the long run, all production factors are
questions.explanation: By definition, the long run is the period in which **all inputs can be varied**.

questions.question: A company’s expenditure on raw materials is regarded as
questions.explanation: In cost accounting, **prime cost** comprises direct materials and direct labour used in production.

questions.question: The basic relationship between the cost of production and the market

options.text: always reflects the cost of labour
reflects variable but not fixed costs of production
does not rise above variable costs
is determined by the cost of production and the current rate of inflation

questions.explanation: Market prices generally depend on **production costs plus a margin**, which is influenced by inflation.

questions.question: A firm determines its profits when it studies its

options.text: average cost relative to price in the market

questions.explanation: Profit per unit depends on **price minus average cost**; comparing AC with market price shows whether the firm is making profit or loss.

questions.question: An increase in the supply of labour in a factory while other things remain equal will lead to

options.text: an increase in the wage rate and an increase in the number of people employed
a decrease in the wage rate and a decrease in employment
an increase in the wage rate and a decrease in employment
a decrease in the wage rate and an increase in employment

questions.explanation: A rightward shift of labour supply reduces the **equilibrium wage** but increases **employment**.

questions.question: A demand which is positively related to price is true of
questions.explanation: A **Giffen good** is defined as one for which quantity demanded rises when its price rises (over some range).

questions.question: Using the demand–supply schedule in figure Econ1994_DemandSupply_Table, what is the equilibrium quantity?
questions.explanation: Equilibrium occurs where \(Q_d = Q_s\). From the table this is at price N30 with quantity **250 units**.

questions.question: Above the equilibrium point in that market, a further rise in price tends to
questions.explanation: A higher price causes a **movement up** the demand curve (lower quantity demanded) and a **movement up** the supply curve (higher quantity supplied).

questions.question: From the total‑revenue table in figure Econ1994_MR_Table where price is N5 and quantity sold rises from 15 to 18 units, the marginal revenue is
questions.explanation: With constant price \(P = 5\), total revenue \(TR = P \times Q\), so **marginal revenue equals price**, \(MR = 5\).

questions.question: Elasticity of demand is an effective tool in the hands of a producer in that it enables him to

options.text: raise his profits and lower his cost
set his price to maximize his profit

questions.explanation: Knowledge of price elasticity helps the firm to **choose price/output combinations** that maximize revenue or profit.

questions.question: Cross elasticity of demand can be mathematically expressed as the

options.text: percentage change in quantity of commodity X divided by the percentage change in quantity of commodity Y
percentage change in quantity demanded divided by the percentage change in price
percentage change in quantity demanded of commodity X divided by the percentage change in price of commodity Y
percentage change in price of commodity Y divided by the percentage change in income

questions.explanation: Cross elasticity: \(E_{xy} = \dfrac{\%\Delta Q_x}{\%\Delta P_y}\).

questions.question: The basic idea behind brand differentiation under an imperfect market arrangement is to

options.text: create demand for the particular product
enable the product to penetrate the market
enable the product to compete with others

questions.explanation: Product (brand) differentiation aims to **distinguish one firm’s product** so it can compete effectively with rivals.

questions.question: In the long run, a firm in a perfectly competitive market will make
questions.explanation: Free entry and exit ensure that, in the long run, firms in perfect competition earn **normal profit (zero economic profit)**.

questions.question: Output restriction, fixing of prices and creating obstacles to free entry into the market are features of
questions.explanation: These are classic characteristics of **monopoly**.

questions.question: A major shortcoming of the sole proprietorship form of business is lack of
questions.explanation: The business may end with the death or retirement of the owner; thus **continuity is weak**.

questions.question: In the event of liquidation of a private limited liability company, the shareholder’s liability is limited to their total
questions.explanation: Shareholders risk losing only the **amount they invested (paid‑up capital)**.

questions.question: The major factor that causes fluctuations in the supply of agricultural produce is
questions.explanation: Agricultural output is highly sensitive to **weather and climate conditions**.

questions.question: The system of agricultural practice which involves hunting, gathering and growing of food crops for family consumption only is described as
questions.explanation: **Subsistence farming** is mainly for the farmer’s own consumption, not for sale.

questions.question: What is the term used to describe a policy aimed at promoting the local production of goods which are usually imported?
questions.explanation: **Import‑substitution policy** encourages domestic production of goods formerly imported.

questions.question: Labour‑intensive strategy to industrialization emphasizes the use of
questions.explanation: Labour‑intensive techniques rely mainly on **human labour rather than machinery**.

questions.question: Petroleum is the mainstay of the Nigerian economy because it is the

options.text: greater contributor to the growth of agriculture
source of high income for its workers

questions.explanation: Oil exports provide the **bulk of Nigeria’s foreign‑exchange earnings**.

questions.question: An indigenous company wholly owned by the Federal Government of Nigeria which currently engages in prospecting for oil is
questions.explanation: The **NNPC** is Nigeria’s state‑owned oil corporation.

questions.question: An increase in both the legal reserve ratio and the discount rate has the effect of

options.text: increasing the quantity of money in circulation
decreasing the quantity of money in circulation

questions.explanation: Higher reserve and discount rates restrict bank lending, **reducing the money supply** (and indirectly increasing the value of money).

questions.question: Inflation in the Nigerian economy may be fueled by increase in

options.text: the dollar price of crude oil alone

questions.explanation: Rising **government spending** increases aggregate demand and can cause demand‑pull inflation.

questions.question: Gresham’s law in economics shows that

options.text: good money drives out bad money
bad money drives out good money
the value of money varies inversely with the price level
gold must be available to maintain the value of paper money

questions.explanation: Gresham’s law: **‘Bad money drives out good’** when both are legal tender at a fixed rate.

questions.question: Monetary policy aimed at reducing demand‑pull inflation in the country may be carried out through

options.text: increase in taxation of private companies, public corporations and private individuals
increase in cash‑reserve ratio of commercial banks and sales of government securities
decrease in government expenditure on education
direct price control in the market place

questions.explanation: Tight **monetary policy** uses higher reserve requirements and open‑market sales to reduce money supply and aggregate demand.

questions.question: A progressive tax structure is designed to

options.text: take more from the income of the poor
take more from the income of the rich
take equal proportion of income from both the rich and the poor
reduce the problems emanating from tax imposition

questions.explanation: In a **progressive tax**, the average tax rate rises with income; high‑income earners pay a higher **proportion** of their income.

questions.question: Taxes and government expenditures are instruments of
questions.explanation: Government spending and taxation form **fiscal policy**.

questions.question: The national income of a country indicates that the gross national income (GNI) was N17,700 million and the gross domestic product (GDP) was N16,800 million. The difference of N900 million represents
questions.explanation: By definition, \(GNI = GDP + \text{net factor income from abroad}\); so the difference is **net income from abroad**.

questions.question: If national income rises by 6% and population rises by 3%, per capita income will
questions.explanation: Approximate growth of per capita income = growth of income minus growth of population: \(6\% - 3\% = 3\%\).

questions.question: One of the ways by which the government can speed up economic development is through the

options.text: increase in consumption pattern of the people
encouragement of savings, investment and equitable distribution of goods and services
increase in the rate of population growth so as to ensure that the country has a large labour force
encouragement of importation of raw materials to produce consumer goods

questions.explanation: Higher **savings and investment** and fairer distribution support faster, sustainable development.

questions.question: A sustained increase in the production of goods and services in a country is called economic
questions.explanation: **Economic growth** refers to a sustained increase in real output or income over time.

questions.question: One of the techniques for rectifying a deficit balance of payments is
questions.explanation: A **devaluation** makes exports cheaper and imports dearer, helping to correct a deficit.

questions.question: The main objective of the Economic Community of West African States (ECOWAS) is to

options.text: establish a West African Development Bank
introduce a common currency for the sub‑region
promote the free movement of persons, goods and services within the sub‑region

questions.explanation: A key ECOWAS objective is **free movement of people, goods and services** within West Africa.

questions.question: In international trade, shipping and other freight charges are treated as
questions.explanation: Freight and insurance are **services**, recorded as **invisible items** in the current account.

questions.question: A situation in which a commodity is sold abroad below its cost of production in the home country is known as
questions.explanation: **Dumping** is exporting goods at prices lower than the cost of production or the domestic price.

questions.question: The borrowing rights of a member country of the International Monetary Fund are determined by

options.text: the seriousness of the country’s economic problems
the size of its gold reserve

questions.explanation: A member’s access to IMF resources is largely based on its **financial quota** in the Fund.
